item.title: Why Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Bringing Back One Unique Cold War Feature is a Big Deal
item.description:
Highlights

  • Black Ops 6 brings back player choice with expanded dialogue options, allowing for a tailored gameplay experience.
  • The game builds upon Cold War's successful mechanic of player choice affecting the outcome of the game.
  • Black Ops 6 promises multiple ways to complete missions, diversifying gameplay for a more immersive experience.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 is set to be the first Black Ops installment in four years, and months of speculation and questions have finally been given some answers. The recent Xbox Games Showcase offered an official look at Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 with a gameplay trailer, and it's definitely not skimping on the action and espionage.

Although the Black Ops 6 gameplay trailer offers plenty of action and confirms that the game takes place during the end of the Gulf War, one of the most exciting features to look forward to is the game building upon a mechanic from its predecessor, Cold War . A particularly interesting feature in Cold War was the game's experimentation with player choice affecting the outcome of the game, and Black Ops 6 is taking this even further with more in-depth dialogue options.

Black Ops 6 Brings Back One of Cold War's Best Features

The dialogue options in Cold War were some of the best additions to the franchise, bringing a fresh new spin to the game's campaign. Cold War 's embrace of player choice brought forth some compelling consequences, and Black Ops 6 is looking to expand upon the mechanic. Cold War 's dialogue choices could make some drastic changes to the game, and Black Ops 6 seems to be diving even deeper into these dialogue trees, which is one of the most exciting pieces of information to be revealed.

Black Ops 6 Expands Upon Dialogue Trees and Player Choice

Instead of just offering a straightforward campaign story like most Call of Duty games do, it seems like Black Ops 6 will offer a more tailored gameplay experience that allows players to pave their own way through the story. Cold War 's campaign was one of the strongest to grace the franchise in recent years, and the dialogue options and player choices were partially responsible for the campaign's success.

After the disappointment in Modern Warfare 3 's campaign, there is a lot of hope for Black Ops 6 to bring back the heat when it comes to a compelling wartime story. Black Ops 6 is attempting to elevate the dialogue trees to the next level with teammate interactions in safe houses. Through these dialogue options, players will get to connect closer to teammates while also getting more in-depth knowledge about the game's story, allowing players to really dig deeper for information in a way that is also immersive.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 is set to launch on October 25 of this year.

Not only is Black Ops 6 set to expand upon dialogue options, but the game also promises multiple ways to complete the campaign's missions. In Cold War , there were several options presented throughout the story that could dramatically alter the outcome of certain missions, especially the final one, and Black Ops 6 taking the same approach is a promising sign for the successor. Black Ops 6 's campaign may not be perfect, since a connection to the internet is required to play, but continuing the focus on presenting players with multiple options is a silver lining.

A New Trend for Call of Duty

Building upon Cold War 's dialogue tree mechanics could signal a new trend for the Call of Duty franchise, or at least the Black Ops series. With Call of Duty being such a long-running series of games, it's clear that the general formula works for many players. However, further evolving and experimenting with how to make Call of Duty more immersive and not as straightforward could be the key to breathing new life into the franchise.

Raven Software and Treyarch are clearly seeking to diversify Call of Duty 's gameplay with Black Ops 6 , and it will be exciting to see how far the developers take the mechanics. Emphasizing player choice brought a compelling layer to Cold War , and it will be interesting to see how it has evolved with Black Ops 6 .

item.title: Hawked Interview: Dev Discusses Class Card Balance and Custom Card Competition
item.description:
Hawked , the comic book-inspired, live-service extraction shooter by MY.GAMES, recently received its first major update with Issue 2. New content includes a new enemy type as well as more firearms and artifacts, but the biggest change hitting Hawked is the game's Class Card system. The new system grants players unique bonuses when they are equipped with specific loadouts of artifacts, Ward, and Exo gear, tailoring a Renegade's gameplay to specific archetypes.

Game Rant recently spoke with MY.GAMES' Dmitry Tabakov about the intent and aspirations behind the new system, as well as MY.GAMES' future plans for Hawked . The following transcript has been edited for brevity and clarity.

A Primer to Hawked Loadouts

Q: What inspired Hawked ’s new Class Card system?

Tabakov: We wanted to make it easier for players to learn about our loadout system which currently allows for over 10,000 combinations of Gear and Artifacts. We wanted to provide players with easier and more engaging choices right from the get-go, and with time, players will find something to their liking.

Class Cards will help them understand the wider ecosystem of how Gears and Artifacts interact and factor into roles like support, hunter, explorer, and so on when playing on X-Isle. Additionally, for more veteran players, Class Cards add a bit of variety to the metagame, with opportunities to try out new playstyles and level up the Cards to higher rarities.

Q: How does Hawked 's Card system vary from class systems in other extraction shooters?

Tabakov: There are some familiar building blocks of course, but arguably the biggest change is that we came from a completely customizable environment and then added this as a layer on top. It’s a bit gentler in its implementation and it exists in an ecosystem where players already have a lot of freedom.

Normally, choices between active and passive effects are not that free, and there’s also the collection element of extracting Artifacts from the island before you can use them. The Class Card system is layered on top of that with another collectible element of unlocking and leveling up Class Cards to complete the collection.

Q: How does this system change up Hawked ’s core gameplay?

Tabakov: While we’re still super keen on people creating their own loadouts, Class Cards offer an easy way to try out a different playstyle than you might usually do. We’re trying to make that as smooth as possible for players. Whether you are a new player who needs a little bit of guidance getting to grips with all the possible loadout combinations, or a veteran who has mastered the meta and is looking for more of a challenge, Class Cards give you another thing to work on since they can be upgraded similarly to Artifacts and Gears.

Balanced to Taste in Hawked

Q: How many Class Cards is the system launching with?

Tabakov: We’re launching with 11 Class cards, roughly mapped to archetypes we feel are engaging. Currently, there are about 10,000 combinations players can make, so it wasn’t easy to create just 11 classes, but we wanted them to feel distinct from one another and also not overwhelm players.

Q: What kind of work went into balancing Class Cards for multiplayer? Are players incentivized to cover a variety of roles in their squad?

Tabakov: Yes, they are intended to channel certain archetypes, a mix of which we feel you’d like on your team. While the loadouts are locked in, the trade-off in return is that they offer an additional bonus that’s thematically linked to the Class Card.

That might include something like extra ranged damage when you’re in disguise. For the sake of balance, a Renegade without a Class Card still gets a bonus with increased damage from their Traverser.

Q: Are any classes particularly effective for Hawked ’s PVE?

Tabakov: The Rowan Rocksteady Class Card is a very solid pick since it has some great area of effect damage, which is really helpful for clearing out groups of enemies quickly (since Disciples and other monsters tend to hunt in large packs). Another strong pick is Pietro Pop-Off, which allows players to shoot their weapons for a long time without reloading while causing additional damage. That should be helpful for both clearing packs and defeating stronger enemies.

Rewarding Legendary Renegades in Hawked

Q: Which rewards are associated with gaining Mastery over a specific Class?

Tabakov: Similar to Artifacts, players can upgrade their Class Card over four Mastery levels (Common, Uncommon, Rare, Epic, and Legendary). Each time you upgrade the card, you get more rewards. You can increase your Card’s Mastery level by extracting Artifacts while having it equipped, but to reach the highest Mastery you’ll have to complete a thematic Mastery Quest unique to that Class Card.

Q: Is there anything else you would like our readers to know?

Tabakov: Narratively, Class Cards represent legendary Renegades, but since we consider our players part of our narrative, we want to complete that circle. From May 27 until June 3, we ran a competition for players to create their very own Class Card, and one lucky winner will have their Class Card featured in-game and join the pantheon of legendary GRAIL Renegades in a future update.

[END]

item.title: LEGO Fortnite: All Difficulties, Explained
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Cozy Mode
  • Survival Mode
  • Sandbox Mode
  • Expert Mode

LEGO Fortnite is a fun sandbox survival experience that players can dive into right from the start. Though it differs rather drastically from its Battle Royale counterpart, LEGO Fortnite provides endless crafting and building fun, allowing players to create and upgrade their village and improve their survivability. Much like other games in the survival genre, LEGO Fortnite offers different modes, catering to both casual and hardcore players alike.

The v30.10 update for LEGO Fortnite saw the debut of two additional game modes, along with additional world settings for players to customize to their liking. Each mode provides a unique experience for players and offers their own level of difficulty. From Cozy Mode to the infamous Expert Mode, here are the difficulties of LEGO Fortnite explained!

Cozy Mode

Cozy Mode is the perfect mode for beginners and players looking for a more casual experience in LEGO Fortnite . In this mode, players can expect to face off against easier enemies , along with not having to worry about surviving the heat or cold within the different biomes of the world. Other neat benefits include having unlimited stamina and removing hunger , allowing players to relax and enjoy their adventure.

Here is a breakdown of the default settings for Cozy Mode:

Enemies

On

Enemy Difficulty

Easy

Storm-Wild Enemies

Off

Hunger

Off

Temperature

Off

Stamina

Off

Player Elimination

Respawn

Drop Inventory Upon Elimination

Off

Friendly Creatures

On

Friendly Damage

Off

Villagers

On

Power System

Off

Village Animals Remove on Elimination

Off

Survival Mode

Survival serves as the base game mode for LEGO Fortnite and is essentially the normal difficulty. In this mode, players will experience hunger and stamina consumption , along with facing off against enemies at their base level . Unlike Cozy Mode, temperature is also enabled by default in Survival, calling upon players to gear up in order to survive the cold or heat depending upon which biome they find themselves in. All in all, Survival Mode is great for players looking to build, gather, craft, and face off against mighty foes when exploring the world.

Here is a breakdown of the default settings for Survival Mode:

Enemies

On

Enemy Difficulty

Normal

Storm-Wild Enemies

Off

Hunger

On

Temperature

On

Stamina

On

Player Elimination

Respawn

Drop Inventory Upon Elimination

On

Friendly Creatures

On

Friendly Damage

Off

Villagers

On

Power System

On

Village Animals Remove on Elimination

On

Sandbox Mode

Sandbox Mode serves as a creative playground for players who want to ditch all the survival mechanics in other modes and simply build to their hearts' content. Everything players can build and craft in Sandbox Mode requires no resources , and players can even spawn any item they wish via the expanded inventory system. Other perks of this game mode include the ability to fly by pressing the jump button while in midair , allowing players to explore the world with ease.

Here is a breakdown of the default settings for Sandbox Mode:

Enemies

Off

Enemy Difficulty

Normal

Storm-Wild Enemies

Off

Hunger

Off

Temperature

Off

Stamina

Off

Player Elimination

Respawn

Drop Inventory Upon Elimination

Off

Friendly Creatures

On

Friendly Damage

Off

Villagers

On

Power System

Off

Village Animals Remove on Elimination

Off

Expert Mode

Finally, there is Expert Mode , which serves as the hardest difficulty in LEGO Fortnite . In Expert Mode, players will be greeted with many of the same survival mechanics as Survival Mode, but this time enemies are cranked up to a harder difficulty . Players will also encounter Storm-Wild Enemies , special variants of hostile enemies that have been super buffed by the storm. But that's not all, as players will also be permanently eliminated from their world should they lose all their hearts. The only way to escape this elimination is to craft a Totem Of Return.

Unlike other modes in LEGO Fortnite , many of the setting options in Expert Mode cannot be changed, with the only exception being Friendly Damage, which can be enabled or disabled when creating a new world. Here is a breakdown of the modes' default settings:

Enemies

On

Enemy Difficulty

Hard

Storm-Wild Enemies

On

Hunger

On

Temperature

On

Stamina

On

Player Elimination

Permanent

Drop Inventory Upon Elimination

On

Friendly Creatures

On

Friendly Damage

Off

Villagers

On

Power System

On

Village Animals Remove on Elimination

On

Players will be unable to edit the World Settings once they have created their world in LEGO Fortnite.

item.title: Octopath Traveler 2: How To Get To The Nameless Village
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Where To Find Nameless Village In Octopath Traveler 2
  • How To Visit Nameless Village Early In Octopath Traveler 2

It can be easy to get lost while exploring the grand world of Solistia in Octopath Traveler 2 . The number of branching paths, numerous towns and villages, hidden caves, and more, can test even the most veteran explorers. If you intend to complete the storylines of all eight playable characters, you will need to know how to find the elusive Nameless Village in Octopath Traveler 2 . It is one of the most carefully hidden towns in the game, and chances are that you probably walked right past its entrance.

The Nameless Village and The Abandoned Village are two different locations. The former serves as a setting for Temenos' final chapter. The latter does the same for Castti's third chapter.

Where To Find Nameless Village In Octopath Traveler 2

The Nameless Village is located on Toto'haha, a small island on the southern borders of Solistia in Octopath Traveler 2 . The easiest starting point would be Beasting Bay: Anchorage above the Beasting Village. Make your way east of the harbor until you come across a mountain. Climb the steps and continue going right to enter the Western Tropu'hopu Traverse, which has a level 32 minimum requirement for a full party.

You can also choose the city of Tropu'hopu as a starting point to get to the Nameless Village in Octopath Traveler 2 . Take the western exit from Tropu'hopu and follow the road to reach the same Western Tropu'hopu Traverse.

Chances are that you have already explored Tropu'hopu as Ochette because Toto'haha serves as her starting region. If so, fast-traveling to Tropu'hopu will be much faster than the Beasting Village to reach the Nameless Village.

In the Western Tropu'hopu Traverse, head west and climb the steps. Then follow the path north through the ruins. There will be a small dock past the treasure chest that leads to the ocean. Take the boat here to enter the Southern Nameless Village Traverse, which has a level 45 requirement .

Sail all the way north to find a series of stone arches. Dock your boat here and follow the stone pathway to enter the Nameless Village in Octopath Traveler 2 . From here on, you can just fast-travel to the Nameless Village to save time.

How To Visit Nameless Village Early In Octopath Traveler 2

The Nameless Village is one of the prime locations every player wants to get to as early as possible. While the Beastling town finishes up Temenos' storyline, it also serves as a marketplace to buy powerful early game equipment.

The only problem is that the Southern Nameless Village Traverse is a high-level danger zone. There is, however, a way to clear it while under-leveled to reach the Nameless Village early on to stock up on some of the best weapons in Octopath Traveler 2 .

What you need to do is have the following two sub-jobs in your party: the Scholar's Evasive Maneuvers and the Cleric's Evil Ward. The former reduces the number of random encounters, while the latter makes it easier to escape battles. You will deal with fewer battles, and chances are they will be easy ones. If you do get pitted against harder enemies, or if your chances of winning are slim, just escape and try your luck again.

Castii can use her Inquire path action on the Beastling outside the weapon shop to increase its stock.

item.title: Dragon Age: The Veilguard - The Mortalitasi Explained
item.description:
Highlights

  • Dragon Age: The Veilguard introduces the mortalitasi faction, rooted in Nevarra's unique necromantic culture and the Grand Necropolis.
  • The Mourn Watch, guardians of the Grand Necropolis, monitor disturbances like corpse possession and funeral rites in Dragon Age.
  • The upcoming game will prominently feature the mortalitasi, a new and intriguing faction in the Dragon Age series.

Dragon Age: The Veilguard brings a slew of factions that are making their debut thanks to the game's focus on the North. One of the new factions is the Mourn Watch, which have their roots in the mortalitasi of Nevarra. Nevarra is a central kingdom in Thedas located just south of Tevinter, and is considered a rising power in Thedas. It's also home to the mortalitasi, a unique order of mages who specialize in necromancy. The mortalitasi, or death mages, are central to Nevarran culture, and the Grand Necropolis in Nevarra City is a monument to the importance its citizens place on the dead.

The mortalitasi had never been a prominent faction in Thedas before Dragon Age: The Veilguard . Cassandra's family, as royals, include prominent members of the Mourn Watch, and her uncle was the prelate of the mortalitasi. With Emmrich's presence as a companion, and the option for Rook to be a member of the Mourn Watch, there's a high chance that the mortalitasi and perhaps even the Grand Necropolis will feature in Dragon Age: The Veilguard .

The Lore of the Mortalitasi in Dragon Age

The mortalitasi are little understood outside Nevarra, as necromancy is widely considered taboo. Death in Nevarra is viewed differently to the rest of Thedas, and this extends to their view on necromancy. Nevarrans believe that when a person dies, their soul crosses the Fade and displaces a spirit. The mortalitasi invite the displaced spirit into the body of the recently deceased as an alternative home. Wealthy Nevarrans pay mortalitasi to mummify their bodies and store them in the Grand Necropolis.

Some spirits that possess the bodies of the deceased become concerned with the life the body that hosts them once led. These spirits become confused, and can even take on the identity of their host, unaware that they're spirits. Mortalitasi work to guide these spirits to resolve the problems that trouble them, so that they may return to their true nature and identity.

The Mortalitasi in Dragon Age: The Veilguard

The Mourn Watch, which is the faction that mage companion Emmrich belongs to and is a possible faction the player character, Rook, can join, are the guardians and caretakers of the Grand Necropolis. The Mourn Watch deals with anything that goes awry within its halls, such as corpse possession or disturbed funeral rites. As Rook can join any faction no matter the class in Dragon Age: The Veilguard , it's likely the Mourn Watch are comprised of both mages and non-mages.

The Mortalitasi Debut in the Dragon Age Games

Dragon Age: The Veilguard will be the first Dragon Age game in the series to prominently feature the mortalitasi. While Dorian specialized in necromancy in Dragon Age: Inquisition , he can't be considered a mortalitasi. The only mortalitasi NPC that has appeared in the games is the Necromancer specialization trainer in Dragon Age: Inquisition , who comes from Nevarra to train the Inquisitor. The mortalitasi had a far larger presence in Tevinter Nights , where the short story Down Among the Dead primarily takes place within the Grand Necropolis, and is told from the perspective of a mortalitasi.

Another unnamed mortalitasi is depicted in the story Dread Wolf Take You at the meeting of spies to collate information on Solas. She describes how the Dread Wolf threatened her to no longer bind spirits, and clearly didn't take his threat seriously as she had bound a wisp to her spoon to stir her tea. Solas kills her at the meeting, then frees the wisp.
